> Adding to the thread already in progress=
:
> 
> Having the testcases in inner classes complicates dependency 
> trac=
king  
> and can force unnecessary builds. To some extent, this 
> depends =
on how  
> smart the compiler/dependency tracker is. If you have a class 
>=
 which is  
> reasonably central to your project and you change a separate =

> test file,  
> then the test file is the only thing that gets rebuilt. I=
f the tests  
> are in the java file, then other dependent classes may get =

> rebuilt even  
> if you are only changing the tests (e.g. adding a new 
=
> testcase). With  
> the tests in separate files, I can refactor tests wit=
hout having to  
> rebuild or even touch the code itself. When I am refacto=
ring 
> tests, I  
> want to be able to recompile/rerun after every tiny ch=
ange and  
> turn-around time is important.
> 
> Similarly,  version contro=
l logs are more clear. I can 
> readily separate  
> code changes from test=
 changes. Pure refactoring should not change  
> tests. Test refactoring or=
 coverage improvement should not 
> change code.  
> All other changes shou=
ld touch both.
> 
> I find that the hit is even larger for documentation ge=
neration than  
> for compiling the code. I prefer to have the docs 
> auto=
matically update  
> after every code change.
